Authors: Jonathan, Lim A.P., Thenuardi D.S., Kusuma G.P., Santika D.D.
Title: Stock price forecasting: Review and experiment on time series data processing
Source title: International Journal of Advanced Trends in Computer Science and Engineering
Affiliations: Computer Science Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Jonathan, Computer Science Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Lim, A.P., Computer Science Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Thenuardi, D.S., Computer Science Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Kusuma, G.P., Computer Science Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Santika, D.D., Computer Science Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Stock price forecasting may present a huge benefit for economy sector as the ability to predict future stock prices may help related parties prepare for the predicted or forecasted condition. Many artificial intelligence-related approaches have been proposed, and this paper provides reviews of time series processing in general and stock price forecasting progresses for newcomers to get acquainted with. In addition, experimentation of stock price forecasting on several existing approaches from time series processing in general are provided to gain insight on which approach may perform better and which may merit further research on stock price forecasting task. © 2020, World Academy of Research in Science and Engineering. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: CNN-LSTM; Data Mining; Review and Experiment; Stock Price Forecasting; Time Series Data

Authors: Michele A., Colin V., Santika D.D.
Title: Mobilenet convolutional neural networks and support vector machines for palmprint recognition
Affiliations: Computer Science Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Michele, A., Computer Science Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Colin, V., Computer Science Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Santika, D.D., Computer Science Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Due to the ease of handling with low resolution images, low cost hardware and high recognition accuracy, palmprint recognition has been attracting in the recent years. Many different features extracted of the palmprint image have been employed to perform the recognition tasks. Most of the recognition efforts consequently has been put on the designing and obtaining a relevant set of effective hand-crafted features which is considered to be the drawback of the traditional image based biometric recognition systems. To overcome the aforementioned problem, in this paper we explore the applicability of MobileNet V2 deep convolutional neural networks on palmprint recognition by fine-tuning a pretrained MobileNet neural networks. We also explore the performance of dropout support vector machines (SVM) by training them on the deep features of the similar pretrained networks. The experiments are carried out using datasets provided by Hong Kong Polytechnic University of Science and Technology. The dataset consists of 6000 grayscale images of 128x128 pixels from 500 different palms. It is demonstrated that the proposed schemes exhibit state-of-the-art performance on the datasets. The second scheme, MobileNet V2 based features with SVM classifier, is able to achieve best average testing and validation accuracy rate of 100% outperforming the best previous reported results. © 2019 The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V. This is an open access article under the CC BY-NC-ND license (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/) Peer-review under responsibility of the scientific committee of the 4th International Conference on Computer Science and Computational Intelligence 2019.
Author Keywords: Biometric; Deep convolutional neural networks; MobileNets model; Palmprint recognition; Support vector machine

Title: Content based image retrieval using Bag of Visual Words and multiclass support vector machine
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebon Jeruk Raya No. 27, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Suharjito, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebon Jeruk Raya No. 27, Jakarta, Indonesia; Andy, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebon Jeruk Raya No. 27, Jakarta, Indonesia; Santika, D.D., Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebon Jeruk Raya No. 27, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Content Based Image Retrieval (CBIR) is an image retrieval method that is based on the meta content of an image which is proven to be more efficient than image retrieval method that is based on text or key words. Bag of Visual Words (BoVW) is a popular approach and the most widely used in CBIR problem. In this research, a CBIR method using BoVW and multiclass SVM classifier will be proposed. In BoVW, Scale Invariant Feature Transform (SIFT) will be used as the local features descriptor. This research will use Gaussian Mixture Model (GMM) as the method to do the visual vocabulary generation and Fisher Vector (FV) to create the encoder. The multiclass SVM classifier will use linear kernel, Hellinger’s kernel, and chi-square kernel to do the classification. After the classification, the proposed CBIR will use the classification model to classify query image. After the query image class is known, then the color histogram features will be extracted from query image and dataset which only consists of image in the same class as query image. Datasets used in the research are Corel and Guang-Hai Liu (GHIM-10K). The experimental results show that BoVW with GMM and FV produces higher accuracy than other encoding methods in BoVW which produce a good retrieval result in the CBIR. © 2017.
Author Keywords: Bag of visual words; Content based image retrieval; Image classification
Funding Text 1: Acknowledgment. This work is partially supported by Bina Nusantara University. The authors also gratefully acknowledge the helpful comments and suggestions of the reviewers, which have improved the presentation.

Title: Prediction of Jakarta composite index using least squares support vector machines approach
Source title: Journal of Theoretical and Applied Information Technology
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, School of Computer Science, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Suwandi, E., Bina Nusantara University, School of Computer Science, Indonesia; Santika, D.D., Bina Nusantara University, School of Computer Science, Indonesia
Abstract: An accurate prediction of stock/index price is highly needed by investors and firms to help them make the right decision regarding to sell, buy, or hold their shares. Recently, a new method within the field of computational intelligence, i.e. Least Squares Support Vector Machines (LSSVM), has been investigated on its performance in predicting stock/index price. LSSVM algorithm itself is introduced as a modified version of SVM algorithm, where the computational complexity of Quadratic Programming (QP) problem in SVM is overcome by solving a set of linear equations instead. In this research, an LSSVM model is built to predict the daily close price of Jakarta Composite Index (JCI). As a comparison, other prediction models are built, namely SVM and ARIMA model which respectively represent the commonly used intelligent and conventional model. Experimental results show that LSSVM model outperforms SVM and ARIMA model in predicting the JCI close price. © 2005-2014 JATIT & LLS. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: ARIMA; Jakarta Composite Index (JCI); Least Squares Support Vector Machines (LSSVM); Stock Index Prediction; Support Vector Machines (SVM)

Title: Automatic music genre classification using dual tree complex wavelet transform and support vector machine
Source title: Journal of Theoretical and Applied Information Technology
Affiliations: School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Wongso, R., School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Santika, D.D., School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: A fast and accurate automatic method for music genre classification is needed to manage a huge number of digital music currently available. However this is a non-trivial task because musical genres remain poorly defined concepts due to subjective human perception. In this experimental study, an attempt to combine Dual Tree Complex Wavelet Transform (DTCWT) based feature and Support Vector Machine (SVM) as classifier is proposed. The study focused on classifying four genres of music i.e. pop, classical, jazz, and rock by using strong features such as mean, standard deviation, variance, and entropy. Data used in the study is obtained from GTZAN Collection Data Sets. Based on the experimental results, the proposed approach produces 88.33% accuracy, which is higher than several previous methods that could only obtain accuracy up to 86.4%. © 2005 -2014 JATIT & LLS. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Classification; DTCWT; Dual Tree; Music Genre; Support Vector Machine; Wavelet

Title: Human facial expression recognition using two-dimensional non-negative matrix factorization
Affiliations: Information Technology, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebon Jeruk Raya 27, Kebon Jeruk Jakarta Barat 11530, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Salim, W., Information Technology, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebon Jeruk Raya 27, Kebon Jeruk Jakarta Barat 11530, Indonesia; Santika, D.D., Information Technology, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebon Jeruk Raya 27, Kebon Jeruk Jakarta Barat 11530, Indonesia
Abstract: NMF is one of the new developed methods which is made to make the part-based representation of nonnegative data, for example the image of human face. NMF can reduce the dimension of highly dimensional data such as multimedia data. In many researches, NMF can also be used as classification technique which is done by utilizing the extracted feature from NMF process. So far, NMF and its variation such as LNMF has been used to classify human facial expression. Unfortunately, for high dimensional data such as human faces, those methods are computationally expensive. This paper mainly discuss about the human facial expression recognition technique using 2DNMF. This research is done by implementing 2DNMF for facial expression recognition and comparing its result to that of NMF and LNMF. From the experimental result, it can be concluded that 2DNMF can be used for human facial expression recognition with better accuracy and much efficient time. © 2012 Elsevier B.V.

Title: Rank matrixoptimization on NMF, LNMF and nsNMF for feature extraction on mammogram classification
Affiliations: Information Technology, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebon Jeruk Raya 27, Kebon Jeruk Jakarta Barat 11530, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Luwinda, F.A., Information Technology, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebon Jeruk Raya 27, Kebon Jeruk Jakarta Barat 11530, Indonesia; Santika, D.D., Information Technology, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebon Jeruk Raya 27, Kebon Jeruk Jakarta Barat 11530, Indonesia
Abstract: NMF is a quite good feature extraction and classification technique when compared with other similar techniques. NMF has so many variations. The NMF versions that will be used in this research are NMF, LNMF and nsNMF. NMF in this study will be used as a feature extraction and as for the classification technique, Neural Network method will be used. One of the variables in NMF that affect the quality of features is the value of r (number of base image). Objects used in this research were taken from the mammogram MIAS database. These objects will then be divided into 2 classes, Benign and Malignant. This research will explore what the r value is and which is the best variation of NMF to be used in this case. The results showed nsNMF with the value r = 20 is the best NMF to use in this case.The accuracy value reached 75%. © 2012 Elsevier B.V.
Author Keywords: Bilinear space; Face expression recognition; NMF

Title: Computer aided diagnosis system for digital mammogram based on neural network and dual tree complex wavelet transform
Affiliations: Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebun Jeruk Raya 27, Kebun Jeruk Jakarta Barat 11530, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: David, Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebun Jeruk Raya 27, Kebun Jeruk Jakarta Barat 11530, Indonesia; Santika, D.D., Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebun Jeruk Raya 27, Kebun Jeruk Jakarta Barat 11530, Indonesia
Abstract: Breast cancer is one of the causes of death that often occurred to women. Computer Aided Diagnosis (CADx) is system to determine type of cancer. This system divided into two phases, feature extraction and classification. So far, Discrete Wavelet Transform (DWT) is frequently used for feature extraction. Unfortunately, DWT has severe shift dependence and poor directional selectivity in 2-D and 3-D. This paper mainly focused on mammogram classification using Dual Tree Complex Wavelet Transform (DT CWT) as feature extraction and Neural Network (NN) as classifier. Using this methodology produces accuracy 93.33% for cancer type classification. This accuracy is little higher than DWT. Data obtained from Mammographic Image Analysis Society (MIAS) database. © 2012 Elsevier B.V.
Author Keywords: Digital mammogram; Dual tree complex wavelet transform; Neural network

Authors: Santika D.D., David, Adrianto D., Luwinda F.A.
Title: DT-CWT and neural network for face recognition
Affiliations: Information Technology, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebon Jeruk Raya 27, Kebon Jeruk Jakarta Barat 11530, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Santika, D.D., Information Technology, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebon Jeruk Raya 27, Kebon Jeruk Jakarta Barat 11530, Indonesia; David, Information Technology, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebon Jeruk Raya 27, Kebon Jeruk Jakarta Barat 11530, Indonesia; Adrianto, D., Information Technology, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebon Jeruk Raya 27, Kebon Jeruk Jakarta Barat 11530, Indonesia; Luwinda, F.A., Information Technology, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebon Jeruk Raya 27, Kebon Jeruk Jakarta Barat 11530, Indonesia
Abstract: Dual Tree Complex Wavelet Transform (DT-CWT) is improvement of Discrete Wavelet Transform DWT), where DWT have some weaknesses that DT-CWT can solved that problem. DT-CWT can be used as extracted feature of image. DT-CWT can reduce the dimension of highly dimensional data such as large image. This paper use DT-CWT as feature extraction to obtain feature. This paper use Neural Network for recognition and using extracted feature as input and discuss about finding the effective number of node in Neural Network. Through this research, it can be concluded that one hidden layer give better accuracy compared to two hidden layers. A few number of nodes give same result of large number of nodes. The number of each hidden layer not influence the accuracy, but with few numbers of nodes has better time process. © 2012 Elsevier B.V.

Title: Classification of microcalcification using dual-tree complex wavelet transform and support vector machine
Source title: Proceedings - 2010 2nd International Conference on Advances in Computing, Control and Telecommunication Technologies, ACT 2010
Affiliations: Magister Teknik Informatika, Binus University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Tirtajaya, A., Magister Teknik Informatika, Binus University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Santika, D.D., Magister Teknik Informatika, Binus University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Breast cancer is reported to be the second deadliest cancer among cancerous woman. Statistics show that the case of breast cancer in the world is increasing every year. By analyzing a mammogram, pathologists could detect the presence of microcalcification in ones breast. However, microcalcification could be classified into benign and malignant. The later indicates the presence of cancer. Computer-Aided Diagnosis (CADx) designed to help phatologists determine the type of microcalcification in a mammogram. Usually, it's consist of two steps, feature extraction and classification. In our methodology, we proposed the use of dual-tree complex wavelet transform (DT CWT) as feature extraction technique and support vector machine (SVM) as classifier. Using this methodology, our experimental result achieved good classification accuracy. However, some of the previous researches have shown better results than ours. © 2010 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Computer-aided diagnosis; Dual-tree complex wavelet transform; Mammogram; Microcalcification classification; Support vector machine

Authors: Eiju T., Matsuda K., Yamauchi M., Barnes T.H., Yusrandihardja, Santika D.
Title: Displacement Measurement Using Holographic Interference Fringes Localized at Infinity
Source title: Journal of the Japan Society for Precision Engineering
Authors with affiliations: Eiju, T.; Matsuda, K.; Yamauchi, M.; Barnes, T.H.; Yusrandihardja; Santika, D.
Abstract: Fringe counting techniques are often used in modern laser interferometers for measuring displacement. These interferometers are essentially integrating devices, where the displacement is derived from an accumulated fringe count, that is, they measure travel rather than static displacement. If the interferometer optical paths are interrupted during a measurement cycle, the reference for the instrument is lost and accuracy suffers. In this paper, a holographic technique whereby displacement is measured by analyzing a fringe pattern localized at infinity which is equivalent to Haidinger or Brewster fringes in conventional interferometry is described. The phase distribution of the fringe pattern is measured to high accurcy using phase-stepping interferometry, and then analyzed by computer. Using this technique, in-plane displacements could be measured with an accurancy of about 0.2μm whilst the accuracy for out of plane displacements was about 2μm. © 1993, The Japan Society for Precision Engineering. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: displacement measurement; holographic interference fringes; interference fringes localized at infinity; phase-stepping interferometry
Index Keywords: Measurements; Fringe counting techniques; Fringe patterns localization; Holographic interference fringes; Phase-stepping interferometry; Holographic interferometry
References: Tsujiuchi, J., Takeya, N., Matsuda, K., Mesure de la déformation d'un objet par interférométrie holographique (1969) Opt. Acta, 16 (6), p. 709; Tsuruta, T., Shiotake, N., Itoh, Y., Formation and Localization of Holographically Produced Interference Fringes (1969) Opt. Acta, 16 (6), p. 723; Matsuda, K., Tenjimbayashi, K., Kohno, T., Eiju, T., Straightness Measurement using Holographic Real Time Interferometer (1984) ICO-13 Conference Digest, pp. 316-317; Hariharan, P., Oreb, B.F., Brown, N., A Digital Phase Measurement System for Realtime Holograhic Interferometry (1982) Opt. Commun., 41 (6), p. 393
